text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with meatless meatballs that's
right no animals were harmed in the
making of this recipe I mean we did take
a couple eggs and pulled out a few
utters but I don't consider that harming
them in fact quite the contrary but
anyway thanks to the magic of mushrooms
a meatless but still completely
delicious meatball is possible and this
is how you do it
so we're gonna start by chopping up a
couple pounds of mushrooms so I want you
to take your longest sharpest knife and
chop those nice and small
all right you for something like the
size of a kernel of corn a little
smaller than what you see here is fine
but don't go any bigger than this we
need millions of little pieces of
mushroom and one size chopped we're
going to throw that into a large skillet
set over medium high heat with about a
tablespoon olive oil in there we're
gonna put in a big pinch of salt and
we're going to Brown these mushrooms and
you know what happens right the salt
draws out the water they get all wet
they boil in their own juices but then
that evaporates that's what all that
steams from and as soon as that pan
dries out how much you go ahead and
throw a nice chunk of butter in there
turn the heat down to medium and just
cook those mushrooms until they're
nicely browned and this truly is
critical if you're not going to brown
your mushrooms this meatless meatballs
meaty and people will be like hey your
meatless meatballs Hayes meatless and we
don't want that so just cook those
mushrooms in that butter until they're
beautifully golden brown so something
like that at that point we're going to
go ahead and add in some minced onions
and we're going to cook those onions
over medium heat for about five minutes
until they turn translucent and yes the
mushrooms are going to continue to
caramelize and brown and they're just
going to keep getting meteor and meteor
and meteor so again this really is the
critical step take your time make sure
your mushrooms are beautifully browned
and once they are we're going to go
ahead and turn off the heat and stir in
our minced garlic and yes that's a lot
of garlic but these are meatballs and
even though the heats off there's enough
heat in that pan and in those mushrooms
to take the raw edge off the garlic and
that's all we're trying to do so give it
a stir once that's all mixed in we're
going to dump in our oatmeal and I'm
using the quick cooking type the
1-minute oatmeal all right so we're
going to stir that in and remember the
Heat's off we're going to stir that in
and when that's all combined we're going
to let that pan sit and cool to room
temperature before we transfer it into a
mixing
and it's very important it has to be
cool before we do this next step and the
reason for that is because the next step
is to mix in some finely grated Parmesan
cheese and if this mixture was hot that
would not work out too well so we're
gonna stir our finely grated cheese into
this cooled oatmeal mushroom mixture and
at that point we're going to add some
very traditional meatball ingredients
all right we're going to do some plain
breadcrumbs a whole bunch of freshly
chopped to tell you parsley all right
one egg although eventually there's
going to be two eggs all right we're
going to season it up with some pepper
some salt and a little cayenne and then
a little pinch of dry oregano not too
much just a pinch oregano a very meaty
herb and then I'm going to take a fork
and stir that together all right so like
I said there's going to be two eggs in
this the first one's for a mixin and the
second one's for a Molden so I like to
mix this up with just one egg in first I
think it mixes better and you're going
to have kind of a dry crummy mixture
like that at that point dump in your
second egg and once that one's mixed in
you'll see we'll have a beautifully
pressable moldable meatless meatballs
cure and don't forget you can always
pinch off a little piece and taste it
for salt and seasoning you could
probably tell raw but you can cook a
little piece if you want and although
technically we could form these into
meatballs now we're not going to you
must wrap this up and store it in the
refrigerator for at least at least four
hours much much better overnight okay we
need time for the flavor to develop and
even more importantly the texture to
develop so try to let this sit overnight
if you can after which we can form our
meatballs and by the way the rest of
this recipe is pretty much going to be
standard meatball procedure I'm going to
use a little sorbet scoop to scoop these
out or you can just do with your hands
but this way they come out all the same
size so I'm going to scoop those out
onto a lined baking sheet and then once
that mixture is portioned we have a very
important decision to make do we want
our meatless meatballs to have kind of
an irregular rough surface or do we want
our balls smooth I kind of like the
smooth look so I like to give them a
little roll between the palms to smooth
them out just like regular meatballs so
that's just an appearance thing the
rolling of the balls would be officially
optional but I'm going to do it and once
your meatballs are prepped we're going
to go ahead and throw those in a
preheated 450 degree oven for about 12
minutes 12 to 15 minutes or until the
outside has a nice brown crust to it I
know they're kind of looking like
meatballs and then to finish
transfer these into your favorite pasta
sauce and let it simmer on low for at
least a half hour I would say an hour's
even better give it a stir once in a
while
remember the starch in those meatballs
are going to soak up some of that liquid
so if you have to add a little splash of
water or broth while these simmer go
ahead of course you should probably
taste the sauce and adjust for seasoning
but you know that and that is pretty
much it so I stood mine for about 45
minutes and I tell you what when I grab
that ladle to serve these up I actually
forgot they were meatless they looked
and smelled exactly like little
miniature beef meatballs I was so
excited
so I served those up of course I had to
do the gratuitous grading of the
parmesan shots maybe a little more fresh
parsley if you're taking pictures and by
the way I did develop this recipe to
celebrate Earth Day because as you know
mushrooms or as I call them earth meat
is about as close as you'll ever get to
eating dirt and there you go meatless
meatballs and of course who cares what
they smell and look like what did they
taste like they were incredibly meaty
and delicious I really was blown away by
these now this is based on our famous
veggie burger so I was pretty sure was
going to taste good I just didn't know
was going to taste this good just very
meaty that parmesan garlic and parsley
really gives it the flavor profile of a
meatball and the texture was almost
identical it really was an incredible
thing and yes they are approved for use
on spaghetti so anyway there you go
meatless meatballs made with mushrooms
so whether you're a vegetarian or devout
meat-eater I really hope you give this
delicious meatless meatballs P a try
